questions.text: Which of the following are transmitted biologically by invertebrate vectors?
questions.solution:
Metazoonoses are a type of zoonoses where the infective agents are transmitted by invertebrate vectors. They multiply and develop within the invertebrates (extrinsic incubation period) before transmission to a vertebrate host.

A zoonosis is any disease or infection that is naturally transmissible from vertebrate animals to humans. They can be classified based on their reservoir hosts into:

  • Anthropozoonoses - transmitted from lower vertebrates to man
  • Zooanthroponoses - transmitted from man to lower vertebrates 
  • Amphixenoses - may be transmitted in either direction

They can also be classified based on the life cycle of the infecting agent:

Category

Mode

Example

Direct zoonoses

Direct contact, fomites, mechanical vector

No developmental or propagative changes during transmission

Rabies, brucellosis, trichinosis

Cyclo-zoonoses

Require > 1 vertebrate host to complete the developmental cycle

Human taeniasis, Echinococcosis, Pentastomid infections

Meta-zoonoses

Transmitted by invertebrate vectors 

Infective agent develops and multiplies within the invertebrate (extrinsic incubation period) after which it is transmitted to another vertebrate host

Arboviral infections, plague and schistosomiasis

Sapro-zoonoses

Has both a vertebrate host and a non-animal (food, soil, plants) developmental site or reservoir

Various forms of larva migrans and mycoses

questions.text: Multiple members of the same community presented with sudden-onset fever, chills, and painful inguinal swellings as shown below. Further questioning leads to the identification of a rat infestation in the locality.  Which of the following is the likely source of transmission of this disease?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario and image showing buboes are suggestive of bubonic plague. It is transmitted by the bite of the infected rat flea, Xenopsylla cheopis. Rodents, including rats, are the reservoirs of infection.

On the other hand, the pneumonic plague spreads from man to man by droplet infection.

questions.text: Which of the following indices is the best determinant of a potential plague outbreak?
questions.solution:
Cheopis index is the best determinant of potential plague outbreaks. If this index is > 1, it indicates there is a high likelihood of an outbreak. 

Related Pearl: Flea Indices

They are useful in measurements of density of fleas.

They include: 

  • Total flea index – it is the average number of fleas of all species per rat
  • Cheopis index - it is the average number of Xenopsylla cheopis species per rat,hence it is a specific flea index. It indicates the maximum explosiveness of the situation
  • Specific percentage of fleas – it is a precentage of different species of fleas that are found on rats.
  • Burrow index – It is the average  number of free living flea per species per rodent burrow.

questions.text: Which of the following rickettsial diseases is correctly matched with their respective vectors?
questions.solution:
Endemic typhus is caused by the bite of an infective flea.

This condition, also called murine typhus or flea-borne typhus, is caused by Rickettsia typhi. Rats serve as reservoirs. The incubation period is 1–2 weeks. The Weil Felix reaction is positive in 2nd week.

The drug of choice is tetracycline. Rodent control is most important and is best done by BHC and malathion.

questions.text: A 38-year-old woman is being evaluated for fever and rash. All of the following can be included in the differential except:
questions.solution:
Rashes and local lesions are not a feature of Q-fever.

It is caused by Coxiella burnetii. The mode of transmission is the inhalation of infected dust, entry through abrasions, or ingestion of contaminated milk. Rarely, ticks can be involved in transmission. The incubation period is 2 to 3 weeks. 

The drug of choice is prolonged treatment with doxycycline. Pasteurization is advised to inactivate the causative agent.

questions.text: Which of the following is false about scrub typhus?

choices.text: Adult mite feeds on vertebral host

questions.solution:
Both adult and nymphal stages of the mite are free-living in nature. They do not feed on the vertebral host.

Scrub typhus is the most widespread rickettsial disease. It is caused by Orientia tsutsugamushi (previously known as Rickettsia tsutsugamushi) and transmitted by the bite of trombiculid mite. The incubation period is 10-12 days.

It presents with a typical eschar at the bite site. It is diagnosed by the Weil Felix reaction, which is strongly positive with proteus strain OXK. It is treated by tetracyclines.

questions.text: Which of the following are the causative agent and vector of epidemic typhus respectively?
questions.solution:
The causative agent of epidemic typhus is Rickettsia prowazekii and the vector is a louse.

The incubation period is 10 to 14 days. Brill-Zinsser disease refers to the recurrent form of epidemic typhus.

questions.text: A patient presents with fever for 1 week, with abdominal distension, loss of appetite, and lymphadenopathy. There is a poor response to antibiotics and antimalarials. The Widal test is negative but  rk39 is positive. Which drug can be used in the treatment of this patient?
questions.solution:
This clinical scenario is suggestive of visceral leishmaniasis. This patient should be managed with liposomal amphotericin B.

This condition causes fever with rigor and chills associated with splenomegaly and hepatomegaly. Though lymphadenopathy is common in most endemic regions, it is rare in India. 

It is diagnosed by ELISA, indirect immunofluorescent antibody test (IFAT), and rk39 which detects antibodies to Leishmania donovani. 

The treatment is as follows:

  • In most endemic regions:
    • Drug of choice - pentavalent antimonial (sodium stibogluconate or meglumine antimoniate)
    • If it fails or is unavailable - amphotericin B 
  • In India and Mediterranian countries, the drug of choice is liposomal AmB.
  • Other drugs - paromomycin and miltefosine

Option B: Fluconazole is an antifungal and is not useful in visceral leishmaniasis

Option C: Linezolid is used in the treatment of MRSA  and related infections.

Option D: Bedaquiline is a newer anti-TB drug used in MDR-TB.

questions.text: Which of the following is not true about Leishmania?

choices.text: Extrinsic incubation period of kala-azar is 4 to 25 days
Post kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis is caused by L. donovani

questions.solution:
Leishmania is an intracellular parasite in the macrophages.

The vector is Phlebotomus (sandfly). Man is the reservoir in the Indian kala-azar. The incubation period is 10 days to 2 years, whereas the extrinsic incubation period is 4 to 25 days. The following conditions are caused by Leishmania:

  • Visceral leishmaniasis or kala-azar – L. donovani
  • Cutaneous leishmaniasis or oriental sore – L. tropica
  • Mucocutaneous leishmaniasis - L. braziliensis
  • Post-kala-azar dermal leishmaniasis - L. donovani

The image below is a microscopic image of the LD body.

 

 

According to the NVBDCP, the management is as follows:

  • First-line - single-dose liposomal amphotericin B (10 mg/kg IV infusion)
  • Alternate - paromomycin + miltefosine for 10 days

Monotherapy with antimonials (sodium stibogluconate) is no longer recommended due to resistance and toxicity. Synthetic pyrethroid is used for indoor residual spraying in all the endemic areas.

questions.text: Kala-Azar is endemic in all these areas except:
questions.solution:
Kala-Azar is not endemic in Assam. It is endemic in the following states in 54 districts:

  • Uttar Pradesh
  • West Bengal
  • Bihar
  • Jharkhand
